Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the technical error message taunting me. As a mentee, I knew I should reach out to my mentor right away—she always said to communicate any roadblocks immediately. But as a telemarketer, I was painfully aware of the ticking clock; I had just one hour left in my shift and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. Management had been clear: no excuses, just results. My phone headset felt heavier than usual, and my fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between drafting an email to my mentor and dialing the next number on my call list. If I paused to explain the technical issue, I’d lose precious minutes, maybe even my chance to hit my target. But if I ignored the problem, I’d be letting my mentor down, betraying her trust in my honesty and communication. My chest tightened as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, feeling the impossible pull of two roles demanding my full attention at the same time.
